verses.text: The fifth angel sounded his trumpet, and I saw a star fallen from heaven to earth; and the key to the shaft of the abyss was given to him.
verses.comment: The 'star fallen from heaven' may symbolize a spiritual being, possibly Satan or a fallen angel (cf. Isa. 14:12; Luke 10:18). The abyss represents a place of demonic imprisonment (cf. Rev. 20:1, 3). Authority over the abyss is given, not seized, highlighting that God remains in ultimate control.

verses.text: He opened the shaft of the abyss, and smoke went up from the shaft like the smoke of a great furnace; and the sun and the air were darkened by the smoke from the shaft.
verses.comment: The imagery of smoke darkening the sun is used elsewhere as a sign of divine judgment (see Joel 2:2, Ex. 19:18). Spiritual blindness and chaos result from the opening of the abyss, alluding to the destructive effects of evil.

verses.text: Out of the smoke locusts came down onto the earth, and power was given to them like the power scorpions have on the earth.
verses.comment: The locusts are not literal insects, but a symbolic army of tormentors, connected to the plagues of Egypt (Ex. 10:12-15) as well as prophetic imagery (Joel 1:4). Their power is limited and granted from above.

verses.text: They were told not to harm the grass of the earth, or any green plant or any tree, but only the people who do not have the seal of God on their foreheads.
verses.comment: Unlike ordinary locusts, these do not target vegetation but people without the seal of God, resembling the protection in Ex. 12 during the Passover. The seal of God refers to spiritual protection given to the faithful (Rev. 7:3).

verses.text: They were not allowed to kill them, but only to torture them for five months. Their torment was like the torment of a scorpion when it stings a person.
verses.comment: The suffering is severe but limited in time and intensity, showing God's restraint even in judgment. Five months is the normal lifespan of a locust swarm, further emphasizing the controlled nature of their torment.

verses.text: In those days people will seek death and will not find it; they will long to die, but death will flee from them.
verses.comment: The torment is so harsh that escape by death is denied. This is reminiscent of the curses in Job and Jeremiah, further reinforcing the seriousness of divine judgment, but also its purpose: repentance is still possible.

verses.text: The locusts looked like horses prepared for battle. On their heads appeared something like crowns of gold, and their faces were like human faces.
verses.comment: The description draws on prophetic imagery, blending features of locusts, horses, and humans for symbolic effect. This highlights the spiritual nature of the threat—both powerful and intelligent, like an invading army.

verses.text: They had hair like women’s hair, and their teeth were like lions’ teeth.
verses.comment: The combination of feminine hair and lion’s teeth may signify both deceptive allure and deadly cruelty—a reminder of the mixed nature of spiritual adversaries.

verses.text: They had breastplates like breastplates of iron, and the sound of their wings was like the noise of many chariots and horses rushing into battle.
verses.comment: Iron breastplates emphasize their invulnerability; the noise echoes the terror brought by an invading army. Again, Joel's prophecy forms a background (Joel 2:4-5).

verses.text: They have tails with stingers like scorpions, and in their tails is their power to torment people for five months.
verses.comment: Their power to harm comes from their tails—emphasizing the hidden and sneaky methods of spiritual attacks. The fixed time for torment again shows divine restraint.

verses.text: They have as king over them the angel of the abyss. His name in Hebrew is Abaddon, and in Greek he is called Apollyon.
verses.comment: The names mean ‘Destroyer.’ Unlike typical locusts (Prov. 30:27), these locusts have a king—a fallen angel—showing an organized opposition to the saints. Spiritual vigilance is needed.

verses.text: The first woe has passed; look, two woes are still to come after this.
verses.comment: This marks the progression of judgments, moving from one disaster to the next. God’s mercy allows time for repentance between the woes.

verses.text: The sixth angel sounded his trumpet, and I heard a voice from the four horns of the golden altar that is before God.
verses.comment: The golden altar recalls the Old Testament tabernacle and the prayers of the saints. Judgments flow from the heavenly altar, suggesting that God’s justice interacts with the prayers of His people.

verses.text: It said to the sixth angel who had the trumpet, 'Release the four angels who are bound at the great river Euphrates.'
verses.comment: Euphrates marked the northern boundary of Israel and often symbolized a line of invasion (Jer. 46:10). Four angels bound there signals judgment unleashed with divine timing.

verses.text: So the four angels, who had been prepared for the hour, and day, and month, and year, were released to kill a third of mankind.
verses.comment: God’s timing is precise—even suffering unfolds according to His sovereignty. The scale of judgment is limited, reinforcing that mercy precedes final judgment.

verses.text: The number of the mounted troops was twice ten thousand times ten thousand; I heard their number.
verses.comment: The army of 200 million is a symbolic figure emphasizing overwhelming force. John 'hears' the number, underscoring the reality and the gravity of this revelation.

verses.text: And in my vision, I saw the horses and those who rode them: they wore breastplates the color of fire, sapphire, and sulfur; the heads of the horses were like lions’ heads, and out of their mouths came fire, smoke, and sulfur.
verses.comment: The vivid description suggests supernatural agents rather than a literal army. The elements—fire, smoke, sulfur—are associated with judgment (cf. Sodom, Gen. 19:24).

verses.text: By these three plagues—a third of mankind was killed: by the fire, the smoke, and the sulfur that came out of their mouths.
verses.comment: The plagues repeat the elements of divine wrath from earlier judgments. Yet, only a third are killed, implying, as before, a call to repentance and the church's role as an instrument of prayer and intercession.

verses.text: For the power of the horses is in their mouths and in their tails; for their tails are like serpents, having heads, and with them they harm.
verses.comment: Serpent imagery points to deception and satanic influence (cf. Num. 21:6; Gen. 3:1). The judgment is both direct and subtle, requiring discernment and fidelity to apostolic teaching.

verses.text: The rest of mankind, who were not killed by these plagues, did not repent of the works of their hands so as not to worship demons and idols of gold, silver, bronze, stone, and wood, which cannot see, hear, or walk.
verses.comment: Idolatry is linked with demon-worship (Deut. 32:17), and the reference to 'the works of their hands' highlights the root problem: stubborn hearts. True worship is central to resisting deception—implying the importance of proper liturgy and sacramental life (cf. Acts 2:42).

verses.text: They did not repent of their murders or their sorceries, or their sexual immorality, or their thefts.
verses.comment: Unrepentance brings continued judgment. The list echoes the sins forbidden in both Old and New Testaments, showing the continuity of God’s moral law. Frequent repentance, sacramental confession, and perseverance in the faith are safeguards for the believer.
